Project Number: 40222-01 
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee and Investment 
Mechanism (Phase 3) 
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

  CGIM  –  credit guarantee and investment mechanism

Head  J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Senior Advisor  N. Akamatsu, OREI

Team member  T. Goto, Economist, OREI  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The 1997 Asian financial crisis underscored the need for the region to develop bond 
markets as an alternative funding source to bank loans. A combination of excessive reliance on 
foreign currency loans, inadequate hedging, poor corporate governance, and weak financial 
regulation were the primary causes of the crisis. Since the crisis, policy makers in the region 
have undertaken structural reforms to improve corporate governance in financial institutions and 
corporations, and strengthen financial supervision. They also reached a consensus on the need 
to promote the development of a regional bond market to ensure the availability of long-term 
domestic currency funding, prevent maturity and currency mismatches, mobilize the region’s 
savings for regional investment, and promote regional financial stability. 
 
2.  Thus, the Forum of Finance Ministers of members of the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN),  the  People’s  Republic  of  China,  Japan,  and  the  Republic  of  Korea 
(collectively ASEAN+3) established the Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI) in 2003. The ABMI 
promotes the development of a regional bond market, in particular by facilitating access to this 
market by a wide variety of issuers, and removing policy and regulatory impediments.  
 
3.  Members identified four priority areas essential to building a deep and well-functioning 
bond market: (i) the creation of new securitized debt instruments; (ii) the establishment of a 
credit  guarantee  and  investment  mechanism  (CGIM);  (iii)  the  establishment  of  a  regional 
settlement and clearance system; and (iv) the enhancement of credit rating systems. These 
activities  aim  to  generate  a  larger  volume  of  new  bond  issuances  denominated  in  Asian 
currencies,  improve  the  flow  of  credit  information  on  debt  issuers,  and  build  the  market 
infrastructure to support cross-border issuance and investment. 
 
4.  The ABMI Task Force 1, cochaired by the People’s Republic of China and Thailand, has 
requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to administer a technical assistance (TA) project 
that will make the necessary preparations for the establishment of CGIM. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The concept paper of the TA was approved by the 
managing director general on 29 April 2009.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  ADB  has  funded  two  TA  projects  for  the  establishment of  CGIM.  The  first  project, 
ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee Mechanism, established that there was sufficient demand for 
the facility and a market gap to be filled, and so it was essential for the facility to have a high 
credit rating. Various organizational options were presented for consideration.2 
 
6.  The  second  project,  ASEAN+3  Regional  Guarantee  and  Investment  Mechanism 
Phase 2,  undertook a more detailed assessment of the organizational options. Phase 2 fleshed 
out the structure and key elements of CGIM, including financial and operational policies, human 
resource policies, governance structure, demand estimates, and detailed financial projections to 
determine capital requirements.3 Based on the results of the TA, ASEAN+3 members agreed on 
the following key points with regard to CGIM. 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 June 2009. 
2  ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee Mechanism. Manila (TA 6127-REG, approved 
on 27 October, $500,000). A supplementary budget amounting to $435,000 was approved on 5 January 2005. 
3  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee and Investment Mechanism Phase 2. Manila 
(TA 6373-REG, approved on 18 December, $500,000). A supplementary budget amounting to $400,000 was 
approved on 9 December 2008.

2   
 
7.  First, the rationale for establishing CGIM is to promote the development of domestic and 
regional bond markets by improving companies’ access to bond markets. Its main purpose is to 
provide credit guarantees to domestic and cross-border issuers seeking to meet their funding 
needs in local currencies. Its role is to address market failures and fill a gap in the market by 
enhancing investment grade issuers’ access to debt markets. This means that CGIM will offer 
financial services not currently available in the market, and complement products currently 
offered by financial institutions. It will not compete with existing financial institutions. To ensure 
its effectiveness, CGIM must have an AAA rating. 
 
8.  Based on the outcome of the demand study completed in 2008 and depending on the 
size of its operations, CGIM could significantly address current market failures evident in the 
very restricted access for potential bond issues (rated below AA but above investment grade 
BBB) and the short-term maturity of local currency bonds. The absence of local institutions that 
provide third party guarantees for local bond issues as a business line is a critical market gap 
that CGIM would be able to fill. Market analysis shows that two main groups of issuers will 
particularly benefit from CGIM’s services: corporate bond issuers and companies engaged in 
public–private partnership projects. CGIM will make it possible for corporate issuers to raise 
funds for medium- to long-term projects, by providing an alternative source of funds to bank 
loans, and lowering the refinancing risk for investment grade issuers. It should also prove 
attractive to companies engaged in public–private partnership projects by enabling them to (i) 
raise long-term funding to finance capital expenditure against projected cash flows, (ii) match 
liabilities with assets, and (iii) reduce the refinancing risk. CGIM will also make it possible for a 
company  in  ASEAN+3  to  issue  bonds  in  any  of  the  13  member  countries  with  its  credit 
guarantee. 
 
9.  Second, CGIM will be established as a trust fund of ADB. Its corporate governance will 
be guided by international best practice. CGIM’s governance structure aims to ensure that 
CGIM is managed and operated in the best interests of its contributors and stakeholders, and 
that the purposes and objectives of CGIM are achieved in the most efficient, accountable, 
transparent, and socially responsible manner. CGIM will have operational independence and 
will be governed and operated according to its own articles of agreement, which lay down the 
corporate governance structure of CGIM.  
 
10.  The highest decision-making organ of CGIM will be the meeting of contributors—the 
principal mechanism by which contributors exercise ownership, governance, and control rights 
and responsibilities. It determines the strategic objectives of CGIM, decides on the use and 
distribution  of  profits,  appoints  the  members  of  its  board  of  directors,  and  reviews  the 
operational and financial performance of CGIM. The board of directors, the second highest 
decision-making body, will lead, guide, and perform oversight over executive management. It 
will ensure that management operates in the best interests of the contributors, and that the 
strategic decisions of the meeting of contributors are fully and efficiently implemented. 
 
11.  Executive decision-making powers are vested in the executive committee, which reports 
and is accountable to the board of directors, and ultimately to the contributors. The executive 
committee will be headed by a chief executive officer who is appointed by the trustee upon the 
approval of the meeting of the contributors. CGIM’s main business of providing guarantees of 
bond issues and investments requires a robust and rigorous system of risk assessment and 
management at the operational level in the form of a guarantee and investment committee. The 
board of directors will determine the committee’s membership and specific mandate. Other

3
committees may be created at the executive level where appropriate and as determined by the 
board of directors and the chief executive officer. 
 
12.  Third, as announced by the ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers’ Meeting on 3 May 2009, CGIM 
will be established with an initial capital of $500 million on a pilot basis. CGIM’s capital, which 
will be fully paid-in (not callable), will be increased once the initial amount is fully committed. 
Subsequently, however, ASEAN+3 has agreed to raise the initial capital of CGIM up to $700 
million. CGIM will not borrow from any source and will operate strictly on the basis of its paid-in 
capital to limit shareholders’ exposure to their contribution to the paid-in capital. To ensure 
financial viability and for CGIM to maintain an AAA international rating, it will operate strictly on 
commercial  principles,  adopt  international  best  practice  in  risk  management,  and  avoid 
providing guarantees to issuers or borrowers with a high probability of default, even during an 
economic downturn. It will also comply with all relevant ADB operational policies, including the 
Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date),  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the 
Financing of Terrorism Policy (2003), and Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
13.  Fourth, to ensure the effectiveness and integrity of its operations, CGIM will keep core 
operational functions in-house, and will not outsource these operations to a third party. In line 
with international best practice, human resource policy will be based on market-related criteria 
and remuneration. This will enable CGIM to attract and retain professionals with the skills and 
expertise necessary to effectively manage and operate CGIM and retain its core operational 
functions in-house. Senior executives, including the chief executive officer, chief investment or 
risk  officer,  the  finance  director, and  other  senior  members  of  management  will  be  highly 
qualified professionals recruited through an international, open, and competitive process. 
 
14.  Fifth, ASEAN+3 member countries have agreed to convene technical meetings over the 
first half of 2010 to further discuss and agree on a CGIM business plan, capital subscription 
among member countries and ADB, a leverage ratio, and other key elements. It is expected that 
CGIM will be ready to start operations by the first half of 2011. Lastly, at the Minister of Finance 
and Central Bank Deputies' Meeting held in November 2009, ASEAN+3 member countries have 
agreed to change the name of CGIM to Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF) to give 
a better indication of CGIM functions. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
15.  The TA will assist ASEAN+3 members finalize CGIF capital structure, its business plan, 
and operational policies. The TA will also prepare for the start-up operations of CGIF, including 
the recruitment of CGIF management team and senior staff. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact of the TA will be a more integrated and stronger regional financial system by 
(i) helping to reduce borrowers’ dependency on the banking system and minimizing currency 
and maturity mismatches, and (ii) facilitating cross-border bond issuance. The outcome of the 
TA will be the smooth and timely establishment of CGIF and the prompt commencement of 
operations on the basis of the proposed business plan drawn up in phase 2 and subsequent 
agreements reached by the ASEAN+3 members.

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The following activities will be undertaken under the TA: 
 
(i)  Organization of capital subscriptions and their payment. With the agreement 
on an initial $700 million capitalization for CGIF, ASEAN+3 member countries will 
finalize (i) the arrangements for capital subscription by individual members and 
for payment of the subscriptions, and (ii) the terms of reference for CGIF board of 
directors and its three committees (for remuneration, audit, and internal control 
and risk management).  
 
(ii)  Development  of  financial  projections  and  related  documents.  Once 
capitalization  and subscription  issues  are  resolved  and  agreed  upon,  a  final 
review of financial projections will be undertaken and a business plan will be 
prepared.  
 
(iii)  Acquiring an international credit rating. Before actual business operations 
start, CGIF will acquire its own credit rating to enhance the value of guarantees. 
The TA will help in the preparation of all necessary documents for submission to 
the credit rating agencies. 
 
(iv)  Recruitment of CGIF staff by a recruitment firm. As CGIF will be operated as 
an internationally AAA rated credit guarantee entity, its management team and 
senior staff will have to be highly qualified and will be recruited through an 
international, open, and competitive process.  
 
(v)  Road  shows  on  CGIF.  For  CGIF  to  provide  credit  guarantees  to  as  many 
potential  issuers  as  possible,  it  must  become  known  to  both  issuers  and 
investors. Road shows on CGIF will be conducted in all major ASEAN+3 cities 
including  Bangkok,  Ho  Chi  Minh  City,  Hong  Kong,  Jakarta,  Kuala  Lumpur, 
Manila, Phnom Penh, Seoul, Shanghai, Singapore, and Tokyo. 
 
(vi)  Reinsurance.  Discussions  will  be  held  with  various  financial  institutions 
(including KfW and China Reinsurance Company) to reinsure the contingent 
liabilities of CGIF. 
 
(vii)  Acquisition  of  office  equipment.  This  will  include  procuring  basic  office 
equipment, determining and designing the IT system required to start operations, 
and providing various services including accounting, legal, and personnel. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,370,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Investment  Climate  Facilitation  Fund  under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB.4 The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                 
4  Established by the Government of Japan.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The TA will be administered by the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) in 
coordination with ASEAN+3. The design and monitoring framework presented in Appendix 1 will 
be used to track and evaluate progress in implementation.  
 
20.   Six international consultants will be engaged for a total of 21 person-months, while three 
national consultants will be engaged for a total of 22 person-months and stationed in OREI to 
provide support to the international consultants. These consultants will be engaged individually 
by ADB in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
21.  The recruitment of CGIF senior staff will be undertaken by a specialist from a recruitment 
firm, given that the nature of the assignment entails a single and specific task. The firm will be 
selected on the basis of quality and cost using a simplified technical proposal. 
 
22.  The procurement of basic equipment for CGIF office will be carried out in accordance 
with the ADB Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
23.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months beginning February 2010 and is expected 
to be completed by June 2011. Consultations and meetings with ASEAN+3 members will be 
conducted to finalize details of the capital subscription and payment, and operational plans. The 
financial statements of CGIF will be prepared for submission to credit rating agencies to obtain 
the  international  credit  rating  of  CGIF.  Discussions  will  be  held  with  financial  institutions 
(including  KfW  and  China  Reinsurance  Company)  that  will  provide  reinsurance for  CGIF’s 
potential  liabilities  net  of  its  paid-in  capital,  and  a  reinsurance  agreement  between  the 
participating institutions and ADB will be drafted.  
 
24.  Road shows will be conducted in all ASEAN+3 member countries to raise awareness 
and promote interest in CGIF’s financial products. All knowledge products from the TA will be 
disseminated  through  road  shows,  workshops,  and  seminars.  Information  on  CGIF  will  be 
posted on the Asian Bonds Online website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,370,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for ASEAN+3 Regional Guarantee and Investment 
Mechanism (Phase 3), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Financial sector specialist (8 person-months). The financial sector specialist will 
(i)  work with the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) and ASEAN+3 to 
finalize credit  guarantee  and  investment  facility  (CGIF)  operational  policies  and 
business plans; 
(ii)  assist OREI with meetings with individual ASEAN+3 members to build consensus 
and reach agreement on CGIF capital subscription by individual member countries; 
(iii)   assist OREI in arranging and participating in the road shows for CGIF in 11 major 
ASEAN+3 cities; 
(iv)   work with OREI and the corporate governance specialist to prepare the terms of 
reference for CGIF senior management positions; and 
(v)   assist OREI in acquiring an international credit rating for CGIF. 
 
2.  Corporate governance specialist (1 person-month). The corporate governance specialist 
will 
 (i)  prepare  the  draft  terms  of  reference  for  CGIF  board  of  directors,  its  three 
committees, and senior management based on the articles of agreement; and 
(ii)  work with OREI to present the draft for discussion with ASEAN+3 and finalize the 
terms of reference for the relevant parties based on the outcome of the discussions.  
 
3.  Recruitment firm (5 person-months). The recruitment firm will 
(i)   provide a list of (a) highly qualified candidates with professional experience from the 
private sector for senior executive positions, including chief executive officer, chief 
investment  officer,  and  chief  risk  management  officer,  and  (b)  candidates  with 
experience  in  credit  guarantees  from  the  private  sector  for  professional  staff 
positions; 
(ii)   assist the team of OREI staff in shortlisting candidates for CGIF senior executive 
and professional staff positions; and 
(iii)   assist  in  the  recruitment  and  hiring  of  the  selected  senior  executives  and 
professional staff. 
 
4.  Accountant  (2  person-months).  The  accountant  will  review  and  finalize  the  financial 
projections of CGIF, its financial statements, and related documents for submission to credit rating 
agencies. 
 
5.   Legal expert (2 person-months). The legal expert will 
(i)   prepare  the  reinsurance  (on  CGIF  potential  liabilities  net  of  its  paid-in  capital) 
agreement  for  participating  financial  institutions  (including  KfW,  and  China 
Reinsurance Company) and ADB; and

(ii)  assist OREI in facilitating the discussion among participating financial institutions 
and ADB on reinsurance. 
 
6.      IT specialist (3 person-months). The IT specialist will 
(i)   assist OREI in determining the IT system required for the establishment of CGIF; 
(ii)   design the system to meet CGIF’s needs; and 
(iii)   establish the IT system for CGIF and ensure the system is operational before the 
start of operations. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
7.  A  financial  sector  specialist  (10  person-months),  accountant  (6  person-months),  IT 
specialist (6 person-months)—will support the international consultants as they undertake their 
respective tasks including data gathering, project administration and report preparation.
